;中国正寻求将自己定位为美国的替代安全伙伴，因为它专家表示，中国越来越多地开展“军事外交”，在该地区开展涉及东南亚国家的联合演习。

;

;本月，中国和老挝举行了“友谊之盾 2023”演习，其中涉及一系列武器装备、作战训练和支持行动。中新海上合作演习也在新加坡海域举行，两国在新加坡海域进行了海上反水雷和实弹射击演习。

;

;4月，中越海警在新加坡海域进行了联合巡逻。北部湾，而中国和柬埔寨举行了“金龙 2023”联合演习，其中包括应对模拟恐怖袭击的实弹演习。

;

;民族主义小报《环球时报》援引中国军事专家傅前哨的话说， “在美国一直在该地区挑起事端的时候”，中国将继续加强与东南亚国家的关系，以营造一个和平稳定的环境。

;

;这个问题很可能会在本周末在新加坡举行的香格里拉对话，与亚太地区安全息息相关的国防大臣和政策制定者将出席。

;

;美国海军战争学院教授保罗·J·史密斯以个人身份接受《亚洲周刊》采访的他将增加的联合演习描述为试图恢复到大流行前的行动水平，这也是为了回应中国认为美国及其盟友的强硬行动。

;

;在最近于印度尼西亚举行的 G7 峰会上，美国、日本及其西方盟友就他们对北京日益增长的担忧以及遏制中国的方式发表了同声传译。

;

;“趋势在 [中国国家主席] 习近平的领导下取得了进步，”史密斯说，并指出北京将“军事外交”视为“其整体国际外交剧本的核心原则”。

;

;G7 ‘把头埋在沙子里’气候变化与“临时”天然气投资

;

;然而，史密斯说，由于其“偶发性和装饰性”的性质，中国与东南亚同行的钻探价值“有限”，并补充说这在很大程度上还取决于

;

;“如果中国部署其不太先进或不复杂的平台，则表明这种接触是有限的，并且仅出于外交或公共关系目的进行，”史密斯说，并指出军事外交不能忽视“曝光”和“信号”。

;

;“曝光”是指在演习期间发布有关平台、能力或操作规范的关键数据。

;

; p>;

;例如，如果中国或任何参与国发送先进设备，它将传输有关该平台或操作程序的敏感信息，而这可能出于“威慑、外交劝说 [even ] 未来武器销售的营销”，史密斯说。

;

;“信号”是指有意或无意地传达有关演习目的的信息，无论是为了产生善意还是“向第三国发送信息”或国际社会”，史密斯说，并补充说中国可能会增加在该地区进行此类演习的频率，以此作为打破它认为美国遏制的一种方式。

;

;Blake Herzinger，研究悉尼大学美国研究中心研究员表示，虽然中国曾试图将自己定位为替代安全伙伴，但最近的演习并未反映出新的动态，因为柬埔寨和老挝等国家“已经更多地落入北京的轨道” ...作为新加坡，赫辛格表示，与中国保持积极关系包括“低级别的防御接触”，由于该岛国与美国的“更重要的安全关系”，这种接触不太可能进一步发展。

;

;“低- Herzinger 说，“水平熟悉演习”有助于在中国与东南亚军队之间建立一定程度的了解，“这可能有助于避免更大的问题”，但“再多的建立信任措施也无法抵消”中国破坏其邻国主权的持续努力.

;

;“总的来说，鉴于北京与邻国的争端和欺凌行为的历史，北京不是该地区可靠的安全伙伴，”赫辛格说，他指的是中国与东南亚国家之间的领土争端，以及北京对地区船只的骚扰，例如上个月在南中国海拦截菲律宾巡逻艇。

;

;几十年来，该地区的国家一直在与其地区和西方同行进行培训。菲律宾和美国举行“肩并肩作战”军演，而泰国与华盛顿一起为亚太地区的军队举办“金色眼镜蛇”军事演习。

;

;菲律宾-美国军演以增强外部防御和网络安全能力

;

;新加坡和马来西亚也参加了与澳大利亚、新西兰和英国的五国防御安排演习。本月，新加坡军方还与美国军方在夏威夷举行了 2023 年第 42 次万金油演习。

;

;近年来，日本和法国等国家也与该地区进行了联合演习；东京与越南进行了友好演习，与菲律宾进行了人道主义援助和救灾训练，并于去年首次参加了美国和印度尼西亚联合演习的鹰航盾牌演习。

;

;法国和印度尼西亚陆军和海军在 3 月进行了两次单独的联合演习，而在 2021 年，法国和新加坡海军在南中国海南部进行了一次演习。

;

;让-马蒂厄·雷伊，法国海军上将兼总统海军对外关系部部长表示，作为“全球主权的提供者和美国最古老的盟友，巴黎“与志同道合的国家发展伙伴关系”以确保“自由开放的印太地区、多边主义和尊重国际法律”。

;

;Herzinger 说，东南亚国家应该决定它们的国家利益和最适合它们需要的安全关系类型。

;

;“对于大多数人来说，平衡与华盛顿和北京将是必要的，有些国家更倾向于一边而不是另一边，”他说，并指出美国的训练将“仍然是黄金标准”。

;

;并指出东盟国家转向这些联合训练澳大利亚国立大学博士生 Abdul Rahman Yaacob 表示，与中国的演习是“他们对冲战略的一部分”，中国在该地区扩大军事演习规模和范围的长期能力取决于北京是否升级了紧张局势南中国海。

;

;“一些东盟国家内部将面临压力，不要与中国建立更密切的防务关系，”他说，并补充说，由于该地区国家依赖美国的武器，华盛顿可能不赞成在与中国的联合演习中部署美国武器平台。

;

;“例如，我们不太可能看到新加坡的 F-35B 战斗机参加与中国空军的联合演习，”阿卜杜勒·拉赫曼说，并补充说，与美国的联合军事演习更为复杂，涉及密切协调、指挥和控制以及高度互操作性。

;

;F-35B 主要由美国资助，据说是世界上最先进的喷气式战斗机，能够同时执行制空权和打击任务，同时提供电子战和情报、监视和侦察能力。

;

;新加坡在 2 月宣布将从新加坡采购另外 8 架 F-35B 喷气式飞机美国制造商洛克希德马丁公司将其第五代战斗机机队增加到 12 架。

;

;新加坡 S. Rajaratnam 国际研究学院研究员 Collin Koh 表示，虽然演习为地区军队提供了虽然深入了解了人民解放军的作战方式及其最新能力，但他们并没有在“提供新的作战见解和建立互操作性”方面增加太多价值，而这只能通过与区域外同行一起参加演习才能获得。< /p>;

;南海：越南要求中国船只离开其区域

;

;Koh 补充说，演习还有助于促进东南亚国家联盟在地区架构中的包容性理念。

;

;“通过让中国参与这些演习，他们还促进了人民解放军参与更广泛的东盟范围内的军事演习，例如 ARF 和 ADMM+ 下的那些，”Koh 说，他指的是东盟地区论坛，一个安全平台该地区的对话，以及东盟国防部长扩大会议，这是连接东盟及其八个对话伙伴澳大利亚、中国、印度、日本、新西兰、韩国、俄罗斯和美国的渠道。

;新加坡国有投资者淡马锡控股周一表示，已削减推荐团队的薪酬其对现已破产的 FTX 加密货币交易所及其高级管理团队的投资。

;

;此举是在淡马锡对其对 FTX 的投资启动内部审查后大约六个月进行的，该审查导致资产减记2.75亿美元。

;

;“虽然投资团队在达成投资建议时没有不当行为，但最终对投资决策负责的投资团队和高级管理人员集体问责并进行了他们的淡马锡董事长林文兴周一在淡马锡网站上发布的一份声明中说。

;

;淡马锡没有详细说明削减的薪酬金额。

;

;淡马锡曾表示其成本截至 2022 年 3 月 31 日，对 FTX 的投资占其投资组合净值 4030 亿新元（3040 亿美元）的 0.09%，并且目前没有直接接触加密货币。

;

;淡马锡最近还表示去年它对 FTX 进行了“广泛的尽职调查”，其经审计的财务报表随后“显示它是盈利的”。

;

;FTX 的其他支持者，如软银集团公司的愿景基金和红杉资本也减价了在 Sam Bankman Fried 创立的 FTX 去年在美国申请破产保护后，他们的投资降至零。

;

;有意向包括淡马锡在内的投资者隐瞒欺诈行为，”林冠英在周一的声明中表示。 “尽管如此，我们对我们的投资结果以及对我们声誉的负面影响感到失望。”

;

;淡马锡的 FTX 损失“令人震惊”，但它并不担心：新加坡的 Ho Ching

;< p>;Lim 表示，淡马锡寻求通过投资早期公司实现可持续的长期回报。

;

;“虽然我们投资时存在固有风险，但我们认为我们必须投资新领域和新兴技术，以了解这些领域如何影响我们现有产品组合的业务和财务模型，以及它们是否会成为不断变化的世界中未来价值的驱动力，”Lim 补充道。

;最近几个月，香港已成功为其大学招收了数十名国际知名学者，但一些人表示，有限的实验室空间和缺乏现代设备，以及高昂的租金，可能会阻止其他人选择这座城市。

;

;66 岁的大卫·帕克 (David Parker) 成为浸会大学 (HKBU) 的化学讲座教授) 去年 9 月，他在英国著名的杜伦大学取得了杰出的职业生涯。

;

;在著名的牛津大学获得博士学位的帕克告诉《华盛顿邮报》，香港浸会大学吸引了他来到香港。

;

; p>;

;“值得注意的是，香港浸会大学化学与建立一个由可以在跨学科研究中合作的富有创造力和才华的人组成的社区有关，”他说。

;

;Parker 在英国获得了无数荣誉，皇家学会会员，还获得了皇家化学学会 (RSC) 蒂尔登讲座和银质奖章，以及 RSC 路德维希蒙德无机化学奖章。

;

;这位科学家是在一个旨在吸引国际科学、技术、工程和数学 (STEM) 人才来港的政府资助计划——全球 STEM 教授计划。

;

;但是，在担任该计划的主任约九个月之后香港浸会大学赛马会 STEM 实验室兼全球 STEM 讲座教授，他表示香港院校的实验室设施无法胜任这项工作。

;

;“香港与中国内地、欧洲或美国在提供高质量的实验室研究空间方面，”帕克说。

;

;“化学和生物科学的现代研究实验室空间严重短缺。”

;

;香港科技大学启动全球计划以吸引顶尖学者来港研究

;

;Parker补充说：“许多大学实验室人满为患，缺乏足够的关键设施，例如通风柜或可控温湿度实验室。

;

; “尽管许多大学科学和工程系面临空间压力，但政府仍迫切需要通过拨款建设此类设施来启动现代化计划。”

;

;然而，这位科学家他说，他通过香港赛马会慈善信托基金运营的一项赠款计划获得了数百万美元的资金，以帮助购买帮助建立新研究实验室所需的设备、计算机硬件和软件。

;

; 3 月份香港项目的 39 名学者，其中约四分之一来自理工大学 (PolyU)。约 15% 来自海外，其余来自大陆，具有在西方国家学习和工作的经验。

;

;教育局已告知立法者，该计划招募的每位 STEM 学者都可以申请资助聘请最多四名研究人员协助研究工作。

;

;响树崇史 60 岁，来自日本的机械工程学教授，于 2021 年根据政府计划被城市大学 (CityU) 聘用。

;

;Hibiki 在日本京都大学和美国普渡大学分别工作了 16 年和 12 年，他认为实验室空间不足可能是个问题。

;

;“如果我们必须进行示范研究，需要使用相对较大的实验设备，实验室空间可能是一个主要问题，”他说。 「幸运的是，城大为我提供足够的实验室空间。」

;

;他还赞扬政府和大学的支持，让他拥有所需的硬件和软件。

;

;美国人响核学会院士、大阪大学全球校友院士及日本机械工程师学会院士表示，他是在2019年应邀到香港城大演讲后首次来港的。

;

;“它是与当时的城大校长郭位的谈话让我决定接受香港的录取通知书。 Kuo 对高等教育充满热情，”他解释道。

;

;Hibiki 补充说，香港因其战略位置，很容易为这些国家的教育和研究做出贡献。

;

;来自其他国家也强调了一个与其他行业共同的问题——住宿成本高。

;

;64 岁的陈清彦，自 2021 年起担任理大跨学科研究院院长，此前他也是根据STEM scheme表示，房价和租户监管令他难以在香港安家，他怀疑自己是否会长期留港。

;

;“房屋条件确实是个大问题。在我的生活中，我一直住在自己的公寓里，我们自己的房子里，”他说。 “在香港置业是一个不切实际的梦想。”

;

;Chen 曾在麻省理工学院 (MIT) 等美国顶尖大学工作了四分之一个世纪，并曾在

;

;香港大学的中国内地学者人数首次超过本地人

;

;他在红磡租了一套公寓，但补充说房东可以要求他带着一个离开一个月的通知。

;

;Parker 同意生活成本是香港学者的一个障碍。

;

;“吸引这些人的一个关键问题是住宿的成本和性质，”他

;

;Parker 还强调了在技术、博士和博士后层面受过训练的人才短缺。

;

;“我们需要吸引更多国际研究人员来港，为他们提供良好的培训并帮助发挥香港在创新 STEM 研究方面的潜力，”他说。

;

;公立大学也通过自己的项目招聘人才。

;

;在美国的中国研究人员“关注香港大学的医学教学工作”

;

;香港大学发言人表示，其于 2020 年 11 月启动的“全球教授招聘活动”已从斯坦福大学等知名大学网罗了 44 名杰出学者，普林斯顿大学、耶鲁大学和麻省理工学院。

;

;香港科技大学表示，它最近启动了“30 for 30”人才招聘计划，在生物医学科学、人工智能等六个战略领域招募 30 名高级学者、可持续发展和绿色技术。

;

;与此同时，中国大学指出，在 2020 年至 2022 年期间，根据政府计划或自行招聘，它每年增加约 100 名新的非本地学者，包括助理教授和副教授程序。

;中国助产士为聋哑妇女绘制的分娩指南漫画她的第一个孩子已经触动了大陆社交媒体。

;

;中国东部山东省山东省妇幼保健院的助产士褚红民绘制了一系列漫画，帮助这位未透露姓名的失聪妇女分娩, Star Video 报道。

;

;中国科学家将硬硅太阳能电池变成既薄又软的弹性体正如论文所说，他们的突破性技术在航空航天、可穿戴电子产品和便携式电源等领域有着广泛的应用。

;

;在过去几年中，材料和制造方面的进步使硅太阳能电池的效率取得了令人瞩目的进步。它们现在拥有 26.8% 的光电转换率——接近 29.4% 的理论极限。

;

;硅太阳能电池约占光伏市场所用太阳能电池的 95%。自从制造和发电成本下降以来，它们已广泛用于地面太阳能发电场和分布式光伏发电。

;

;但是，开发具有商业可行性且高效的重量轻、灵活且成本低的太阳能电池——而且可以大规模使用——这是一个挑战。

;

;目前使用的薄膜太阳能电池由非晶硅、碲化镉、有机物和钙钛矿制成。

;

;它们确实“中科院上海微系统与信息技术研究所（SIMIT）新能源技术中心教授刘文柱说。

;

;“但它们的使用受到限制，因为它们的低功率转换效率……向环境中释放有毒物质，在大面积和不稳定的工作条件下性能低下，”刘说。

;

;他的团队已经为硅提出了一种创新结构太阳能电池以使其具有柔性——他们说该研究表明大规模生产也是可行的。

;

;来自 SIMIT、长沙科技大学和沙特阿拉伯石油公司的科学家发表了他们的研究结果发表于 5 月 24 日的同行评审期刊《自然》。

;

;这一发展可能会在可穿戴电子产品、移动通信、车辆移动能源、建筑集成光伏和航空航天等领域开辟新的机遇。

;

; p>;

;随着新进入者关注中国太阳能行业，产能过剩和价格战担忧加剧

;

;该团队首先使用高速相机观察处于弯曲应力下的硅太阳能电池。他们发现开裂总是始于硅片边缘的尖锐 V 形凹槽——他们将这个区域定义为硅片的“薄弱点”。

;

;“了解太阳能电池的破裂行为使我们能够改变硅片边缘区域的结构。我们用更光滑的‘U’槽代替了尖锐的‘V’槽，这有效地分散了弯曲应变并抑制了断裂行为，”该研究的通讯作者狄增峰周三在 SIMIT 网站上的一份报告中说。 “最终的结果是高效、轻便、灵活的硅太阳能电池。”

;

;该策略只用在硅片的边缘，因此不会对电池的功率转换效率产生影响太阳能电池，另一位通讯作者刘正新在报告中说。

;

;“但它确实显着增加了太阳能电池的柔性，具有广阔的应用前景，”他说。

;

;该论文称，硅太阳能电池具有前所未有的灵活性。它的尺寸为 60 微米，可以像一张纸一样折叠。它还可以承受反复弯曲，弯曲半径小于5毫米，弯曲角度超过360度。

;

;研究人员还进行了不同条件下的耐久性测试。在 1,000 次左右弯曲循环后，电池仍保持 100% 的功率转换效率。在负 70 摄氏度（负 94 华氏度）和 85 摄氏度（185 华氏度）之间热循环 120 小时后，它们还保留了 99.62% 的功率。

;

;中国-瑞士团队是否破解了密码使太阳能更便宜？

;

;在风阻测试中，研究人员将电池模块连接到充气的气囊上，并使用强大的风扇来模拟以每秒 30 米的速度吹风的效果急风暴雨。连续空气撞击20分钟后，相对功率损失仅为3.07%，表明其在航空航天领域具有潜在用途，如间谍气球。

;

;报道称，该研究团队的大面积柔性光伏组件已成功应用于临近空间飞行器、建筑光伏和车载光伏。

;

;但团队对制造技术仍持谨慎态度。 “在大规模生产之前，需要进行更多的原位测试，以确保在压力源可能同时出现的现实操作条件下的一致稳定性，”刘文柱在论文中说。

;US President Joe Biden said he and House Speaker Kevin McCarthy reached a final agreement to avert a historic US default after the two spoke again on Sunday afternoon.

;

;“We've got good news. I've just spoken with Speaker McCarthy. We have a bipartisan budget agreement,” Biden told reporters at the White House.

;

;He urged both chambers of Congress to pass the legislation.

;

;Both Biden and McCarthy now have to convince their allies to support the package, while tamping down frustrations on the left and right wings of their respective parties.

;

;The compromise announced late on Saturday includes spending cuts but risks angering some lawmakers as they take a closer look at the concessions. Biden told reporters at the White House upon his return from Delaware that he was confident the plan will make it to his desk.

;

;McCarthy, too, was confident in remarks at the Capitol: “At the end of the day, people can look together to be able to pass this.”

;

;The days ahead will determine whether Washington is again able to narrowly avoid a default on US debt, as it has done many times before, or whether the global economy enters a potential crisis.

;

;In the United States, a default could cause financial markets to freeze up and spark an international financial crisis. Analysts say millions of jobs would vanish, borrowing and unemployment rates would jump, and a stock-market plunge could erase trillions of dollars in household wealth. It would all but shatter the US$24 trillion market for Treasury debt.

;

;Anxious retirees and others were already making contingency plans for missed cheques, with the next Social Security payments expected soon as the world watches American leadership at stake.

;

;Biden and McCarthy reach 'in principle' US debt ceiling deal

;

;McCarthy and his negotiators portrayed the deal as delivering for Republicans though it fell well short of the sweeping spending cuts they sought. Top White House officials were briefing Democratic lawmakers and phoning some directly to try to shore up support.

;

;As Sunday dragged on, negotiators laboured to write the bill text and lawmakers raised questions.

;

;McCarthy told reporters at the Capitol on Sunday that the agreement “doesn't get everything everybody wanted,” but that was to be expected in a divided government. Privately, he told lawmakers on a conference call that Democrats “got nothing” they wanted.

;

;Support from both parties will be needed to win congressional approval before a projected June 5 government default on US debts. Lawmakers are not expected to return to work from the Memorial Day holiday weekend before Tuesday, at the earliest, and McCarthy has promised lawmakers he will abide by the rule to post any bill for 72 hours before voting.

;

;Negotiators agreed to some Republican demands for increased work requirements for recipients of food stamps that House Democrats had called a non-starter.

;

;With the outlines of an agreement in place, the legislative package could be drafted and shared with lawmakers in time for House votes as soon as Wednesday, and later in the coming week in the Senate.

;

;Central to the compromise is a two-year budget deal that would essentially hold spending flat for 2024, while boosting it for defence and veterans, and capping increases at 1 per cent for 2025. That's alongside raising the debt limit for two years, pushing the volatile political issue past the next presidential election.

;

;Driving hard to impose tougher work requirements on government aid recipients, Republicans achieved some of what they wanted. People ages 49 to 54 with food stamp aid would now have to meet work requirements if they are able-bodied and without dependents. Biden was able to secure waivers for veterans and homeless people.

;

;Biden says 'hopeful' on US debt deal within hours

;

;The deal puts in place changes in the landmark National Environmental Policy Act designating “a single lead agency” to develop environmental reviews, in hopes of streamlining the process.

;

;It halts some funds to hire new Internal Revenue Service agents as Republicans demanded, and rescinds some US$30 billion for coronavirus relief, keeping US$5 billion for developing the next generation of Covid-19 vaccines.

;

;The deal came together after Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen told Congress that the United States could default on its debt obligations by June 5 – four days later than previously estimated – if lawmakers did not act in time. Lifting the nation's debt limit, now at US$31 trillion, allows more borrowing to pay bills already insured.

;

;McCarthy commands only a slim Republican majority in the House, where hard-right conservatives may resist any deal as insufficient as they try to slash spending. By compromising with Democrats, he risks losing support from his own members, setting up a career-challenging moment for the new speaker.

;

;“I think you're going to get a majority of Republicans voting for this bill,” McCarthy said on Fox News Sunday, adding that because Biden backed it, “I think there's going to be a lot of Democrats that will vote for it, too.”

;

;House Democratic leader Hakeem Jeffries of New York said on CBS' Face the Nation programme that he expected there will be Democratic support but he declined to provide a number. Asked whether he could guarantee there would not be a default, he said: “Yes.”

;

;A 100-strong group of moderates in the New Democratic Coalition gave a crucial nod of support on Sunday, saying in a statement it was confident that Biden and his team “delivered a viable, bipartisan solution to end this crisis” and were working to ensure the agreement would receive support from both parties.

;

;The coalition could provide enough support for McCarthy to make up for members in the right flank of his party who have expressed opposition before the bill's wording was even released.

;

;It also takes pressure off Biden, facing criticism from progressives for giving into what they call hostage-taking by Republicans.

;

;Democratic congresswoman Pramila Jayapal of Washington state, who leads the Congressional Progressive Caucus, told CBS that the White House and Jeffries should worry about whether caucus members will support the agreement.

; Mon, 29 May 2023 08:20:02 +0800 How the former boss of Hong Kong stock exchange is helping Macau connect overseas investors to mainland China’s small businesseshttps://www.scmp.com/business/china-business/article/3222106/how-former-boss-hong-kong-stock-exchange-helping-macau-connect-overseas-investors-chinas-small?utm_source=rss_feed

;Zhou Yingqun, a 28-year-old Hunan native who has worked in the beauty salon industry for over a decade, never thought he would one day be ringing an IPO bell.

;

;But when Mr Judy, the hair treatment company he works for as a regional manager, listed a brand new type of security in Macau earlier this year, the shy young man said he was over the moon.

;

;“I was very, very excited. I just felt very honoured and excited to be able to participate in such a significant ceremony,” Zhou said.

;

;Having joined Mr Judy in 2020 as a general staff member, Zhou was offered an opportunity to help the company open a new shop last year and own 10 per cent of the shares. It was almost impossible to get bank loans as he had nothing to put down as collateral, so Zhou borrowed the rest of the money he needed to make it happen from Micro Connect, an investment platform co-founded by Charles Li Xiaojia, the former boss of Hong Kong's stock exchange operator.

;

;Mr Judy recently became one of about 4,000 companies in the first batch to list a new financial product called daily revenue obligations (DROs) on the Micro Connect Macao Financial Assets Exchange (MCEX).

;

;Launched in the former Portuguese colony at the end of March, MCEX is the first licensed global exchange for DROs, which can be traded by institutional investors whose funds go to small businesses – mainly shops and small retail outfits – in China in exchange for part of their daily revenue.

;

;It is a central part of Micro Connect's mission to bridge the gap between global investors and mainland China's grass-roots economy by providing funding opportunities to the country's small businesses.

;

;In doing so, it also aims to help develop Macau's financial sector as the city attempts to diversify its focus beyond the gambling industry, into entertainment and innovation.

;

;“Through MCEX, Macau can play a role in introducing overseas capital for China's small and micro-sized economy, which aligns with its goal to develop a finance sector with its own characteristics,” said Samson Cheng, head of corporate development at Micro Connect.

;

;Already surrounded by financial powerhouses including Hong Kong and Shenzhen in the Greater Bay Area, Shanghai in eastern China and Singapore, Macau aims to position itself as an alternative destination fostering financial innovations that may not be allowed elsewhere, according to analysts.

;

;“Macau is trying to have its own path [to develop the financial sector] in a way that's not directly competing with existing financial centres such as Hong Kong as they are already mature in various services and infrastructures,” said Adrian Cheung, dean at the faculty of finance at the City University of Macau.

;

;Through the MCEX scheme, small and micro businesses – a term generally applied to companies with less than about 10 employees – are able to raise funds in a listing similar to an initial public offering (IPO), without having to hand over a stake or control of their firms. It has the additional benefit of giving institutional investors access to an alternative investment instrument that enables them to receive an immediate, daily cash income.

;

;There are more than 70 million small and micro businesses in China, and their total demand for funding is estimated at around 12 trillion yuan (US$1.71 trillion) to 13 trillion yuan annually, according to Micro Connect.

;

;“Macau is well positioned to be an innovation hub given its international free port, its politically neutral stance [and its] preferential business and foreign-trade environment,” said the territory's chief executive, Ho Iat-seng, during this month's Beyond Expo tech conference.

;

;China's small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) invariably find it difficult to access funds. Even though the authorities have over the years called on banks to increase financing for SMEs, the problem persists for many.

;

;Duan Tao, chief operating officer of Hanyangguan, a Korean barbecue restaurant chain, said the company had looked into different ways of raising money, such as venture capital and private equity in the last few years, but the processes involved were lengthy. Meanwhile bank loans came with a rigid repayment schedule – something that weighed heavily on weighed small businesses during the three years of Covid-19.

;

;“Our Shanghai branch was shut down for three months during the lockdown last year, so there was zero revenue,” Duan said. “If we had borrowed from a bank, they wouldn't care if we made money or not. We would have to repay the loan on time regardless. But with Micro Connect … we both have more flexibility in that sense.”

;

;Via its new exchange, Micro Connect is able to exit its investment in a business. The so-called DRCs – contracts signed between Micro Connect and the small businesses – are swapped into tradeable financial instruments, the DROs, which can be bought and sold freely by investors on the exchange.

;

;Small firms can issue additional DROs to seek for more funds via the exchange.

;

;Access to funding via DROs does not come for cheap. The annual funding cost is around 12 to 13 per cent according to Micro Connect, although the small businesses benefit from Micro Connect sharing their revenue risks.

;

;Micro Connect is working to launch the next two stages of the DRO market this summer. An add-on offering will allow small businesses to issue additional DRO shares to investors to raise more funds, while a secondary trading process will enable something similar to the secondary trading of stocks on any exchange.

;

;The company plans to allow the 70 to 80 institutional investors in the current pipeline – mainly asset managers, securities firms, banks and licensed family offices – to participate in the market and start to buy and sell the DROs.

;

;Micro Connect is aiming to triple the number of listed businesses through the DRO scheme to 100,000 next year, raising an estimated 9 billion yuan to 15 billion yuan via the MCEX.

;

;The company hopes to extend the platform's scope beyond China, into regions like Southeast Asia in the future, and gradually make it a mainstream financing channel for micro firms, Cheng said.

; Mon, 29 May 2023 08:20:02 +0800 Why Cathay Pacific discrimination scandal must herald a bill banning anti-mainland bigotryhttps://www.scmp.com/comment/opinion/article/3221918/why-cathay-pacific-discrimination-scandal-must-herald-bill-banning-anti-mainland-bigotry?utm_source=rss_feed
;;2023.05.29 08:15;
;;

;I love new beginnings. You get to dump all that emotional baggage, let bygones be bygones and start afresh. And so, amid yet another scandal for Hong Kong's flag carrier Cathay Pacific Airways, it might be the right time for a change, starting with a new name.

;

;As CEO Ronald Lam Siu-por said in an internal memo, the airline “must reflect humbly, examine our culture deeply and take concrete measures” to recover from the discrimination scandal.

;

;Cathay cabin crew were accused of insulting non-English-speaking mainland Chinese passengers on a recent flight from Chengdu to Hong Kong, an incident which quickly spiralled from a public-relations nightmare to a political crisis.

;

;It is true that management acted swiftly, issuing plenty of statements and repeated apologies. They summarily dismissed the three offending cabin crew and hit back at Cathay Pacific Airways Flight Attendants' Union for attributing the bad behaviour to low morale.

;

;However, it's clear that this isn't going away. It is just the latest and most explosive turn in the airline's saga, after pilots were accused of “slow taxiing” to earn more pay.

;

;It is a long time since Marco Polo wrote his story The Road to Cathay. European and Arab travellers of the day referred to northern China as “Cathay”, but in today's Hong Kong, that name could stir up trouble. The last thing a name should be reminding people of is a time when China was divided.

;

;Times have changed, and this discrimination scandal was bound to be politicised. Chief Executive John Lee Ka-chiu was quick to express his outrage and disappointment in public, accusing the Cathay crew of hurting the feelings of compatriots in Hong Kong and on the mainland and undermining what he calls “the city's existing culture and values of respect, courtesy and inclusiveness”. Lee was in Guangzhou for the opening ceremony of the Guangdong-Hong Kong Cooperation Week. This happened at the worst time for him.

;

;But we shouldn't blame officials for turning up the heat on the airline. Remaining silent was never an option – the government is a shareholder in the airline, having used public money to bail out Cathay during the Covid-19 pandemic.

;

;While senior management at the airline engage in some soul-searching, the Hong Kong government is now forced to face something it has long tried to sugarcoat and sidestep: Hong Kong's culture of discrimination. “The city's existing culture and values of respect, courtesy and inclusiveness” mentioned by Lee is actually a myth – something we wish we had.

;

;Just look at how non-Chinese ethnic minority children have consistently been denied opportunities in an education system that has yet to address language barriers.

;

;The government has provided more funding to schools with non-Chinese-speaking students but the problem persists, as the Equal Opportunities Commission found last year. The commission has also been trying to convince the government and lawmakers to amend the city's anti-discrimination laws to include “intra-racial discrimination”.

;

;I remember a difficult conversation with a veteran politician some years ago, when the city was preparing to legislate against racial discrimination. Tensions between Hongkongers and mainland Chinese were apparent then, and they continue to be reflected in the fallout from the latest Cathay saga.

;

;I asked how blatant discrimination against mainland Chinese in the city could be addressed by the legislation. The veteran politician's answer was hard to stomach: it won't be – we are of the same race, and hence they will not be protected.

;

;We can appreciate now how that would annoy many people. We are of one ethnicity, but the fact remains that many remain unprotected by anti-discrimination legislation.

;

;About half of Hongkongers say discrimination is prevalent in city: survey

;

;Even so, the commission has faced resistance when pushing for legislation against intra-racial discrimination. Tensions boiling over have been played down as “isolated incidents”. Hostility against mainland Chinese in Hong Kong definitely doesn't fit the narrative of telling good Hong Kong stories.

;

;Lawmaker Carmen Kan Wai-mun said that “the legislation should be the last resort”. “It's quite pathetic if intra-racial discrimination is so severe that it has to be resolved by legislation,” she said.

;

;Perhaps the latest Cathay scandal can convince her and her colleagues that it is high time to do the deed. It would be “quite pathetic” not to act now.

;In recent graduation seasons, Wendy Li has promoted government-backed programmes designed to encourage Chinese university graduates to work in the country's vast and underdeveloped countryside.

;

;Such campaigns, under different names, are nothing new, but Li, an undergraduate who works for the student union at a university in Zhuhai, Guangdong province, said the number of applicants had more than tripled this year.

;

;“They seem to have become more attractive this year,” she said. “我们学校有 400 名学生，大约有 40 名学生报名了。 In the past couple of years, about a dozen would do so.”

;

;The authorities have intensified efforts to encourage young people to pursue careers in China's rural areas amid mounting job pressure and President Xi Jinping's calls to “revitalise the countryside” to narrow the urban-rural development gap.

;

;Reminiscent of the “Down to the Countryside” movement in the Mao Zedong era, modern-day initiatives include a Guangdong plan to send 300,000 university graduates to rural areas by the end of 2025.

;

;According to an action plan issued in February, the graduates will work as grass-roots cadres, entrepreneurs or volunteers to contribute to the “return of talent, resources and projects” to the countryside.

;

;Most other provinces have also upgraded such programmes by enlarging the number of people being sent or the range of destinations.

;

;In Jiangsu province, an initiative that previously targeted underdeveloped areas in five relatively poor cities was expanded across the province last year, aiming to send at least 2,000 graduates to rural areas each year.

;

;Such moves aimed to give young people more job opportunities in a tough labour market, said Peng Peng, executive chairman of the Guangdong Society of Reform, a think tank affiliated with Guangdong's provincial government.

;

;“Young people in urban areas have encountered great difficulty in finding jobs due to the influence of the pandemic and the unprecedented number of graduates,” he said.

;

;The unemployment rate for the 16-24 age group in China hit a record high of 20.4 per cent last month, compared with 19.6 per cent in March. Meanwhile, a record 11.58 million university graduates – about the size of Belgium's population – are set to enter the job market this year.

;

;“The second purpose of these policies is to revive the countryside, where talent and technology are most needed,” Peng said. “Rural areas are the weak link in China's road to modernisation, so they must be revitalised – something the top leadership has made a national strategy.”

;

;

;But he said such programmes were different from Mao's campaign in the 1960s and 70s, when millions of young people in urban areas were ordered to live and work in remote rural villages to break the class barriers between the rich and poor.

;

;“It may lead people to remember history, but it's not a forced campaign now, it's up to you whether you go,” he said. “此外，农村地区只是年轻人的一种选择。 It's not the same as in the past, when people were forced to go to designated regions.”

;

;Back then, such destinations included Yunnan province and Beidahuang – the great northern wilderness – a vast region mostly of farmland in the northeastern province of Heilongjiang.

;

;In 1969, a teenaged Xi was sent to the barren Loess Plateau in rural Yanan, Shaanxi province, for seven years, with commentators later viewing his “sent-down years” as a rite of passage that helped hone his qualities as the nation's leader.

;

;For many of today's participants, such programmes are more a transition from university to work – as finding an ideal job becomes more difficult – than a long-term commitment to the development of rural areas.

;

;Li Qing, a 2022 graduate who has been working in a township government's rural revival programme in Yangzhou, Jiangsu province, since the start of the year, said she was preparing for civil service recruitment tests at the same time.

;

;“I was a bit lost when I graduated last year, not knowing what I really wanted,” she said. “Also, I failed the postgraduate test.

;

;“So when I saw this opportunity, I thought it might be a good transitional option, especially as my family had suggested I become a civil servant.”

;

;With a monthly subsidy of “a few thousand yuan” to cover accommodation and transport, she said the job had so far taught her “nothing much except for the way I conduct myself and the government's rigorous work style”.

;

;Graduates face 'fresh obstacles, challenges' as Beijing rolls out 15-point plan

;

;“I wouldn't recommend it to those who want to continue with academic studies or those who are looking for a full-time job, because the former won't have a lot of time to study, and, for the latter, such an experience will be of little help to their future work, and neither will it make a corporate employer look at you differently during hiring,” she said.

;

;Li said most participants from her university in Zhuhai would work as teachers or volunteers at village schools, or village cadres helping to monitor the risk of people returning to poverty.

;

;After two years of service, they could choose to stay or pursue new jobs elsewhere, she said, adding that many would choose to take the civil service exams because they earned extra points towards qualification by taking part in the campaign.

;

;“As far as I know, few have actually stayed and settled down in those villages, as the authorities hoped they would,” Li said.

;

;Can talent dividend keep China competitive as population shrinks and ages?

;

;Joan Huang, a second-year student at a university in Guangzhou, Guangdong's provincial capital, said she was not interested in such programmes because she saw no career prospects in rural areas.

;

;“To be frank, I think this initiative is only getting people to do chores at entry-level positions in grass-roots government bodies,” she said. “The economy in these areas is bad and it's nearly impossible for graduates to launch a start-up, except for maybe a milk tea shop.

;

;“There might be opportunities in large infrastructure or smart agriculture, but these are not for ordinary students.

;

;“If you enter a local company, the pay would be low and may not be enough to cover the university tuition your family has spent. If you go back to big cities after that, then you'll find the work experience in rural areas useless.”

;

;China's urban-rural income gap has remained wide despite a slight improvement in the past decade. Last year, the average disposable income of rural residents was 20,133 yuan (US$2,853), compared with 49,283 for those in urban areas, according to the National Bureau of Statistics.

;

;Stressing that China could not become a real power without strong agriculture and thriving villages, Xi has urged local governments to lure not only university students, but also entrepreneurs and former farmers who had left to find work in cities.

;

;“We should guide graduates, capable people, migrant workers and entrepreneurs to the countryside in an orderly way, and help solve their concerns so that they can stay and start a career,” he told the national rural work conference in December.

;

;Zheng Fengtian, a professor at Renmin University's school of agricultural and rural development, said talent was one of resources needed most by less developed regions that have benefited from China's industrial transfer and poverty-elimination drive.

;

;In a first, more postgrads than undergrads are set to graduate in Beijing

;

;“In central and western areas, some industries and companies have arisen during the push to alleviate poverty, and some have been moved there from affluent areas like Shenzhen and Guangzhou,” he said. “Now they need talent for further growth.

;

;“For individuals, living in a small town may not be worse than in a metropolis – one may be able to buy a home after working there for just a couple of years. The quality of life isn't worse than in big cities.”

;

;Janice Wang, 28, returned to her home village in Anji, Zhejiang province, three years ago – lured back to the countryside by increased government investment, lower living costs and a slower pace of life.

;

;She worked as a teacher in the city after graduating from university in 2016, but moved back home to begin running a bed-and-breakfast in 2020.

;

;While it was hard for fresh graduates to see a future in rural villages, she said starting her own business in the countryside had become a desirable and feasible option after she accumulated some savings from working as a teacher.

;

;“We have well-built roads, good public facilities and fresh air here,” Wang said. “我每天都会遇到不同的客人。 It's not easy work but I feel freer and happier.”

;

;She had not had to worry about renting or buying a home, as the house she was running was her family property.

;

;“Business is not bad, despite some negative influence from pandemic lockdowns in recent years,” Wang said. “There has been an increasing number of retired people, and they have great demand for travelling and cheap accommodation.

;

;“So overall, I have much less pressure living this way.”
